posts.name: Ben W.
posts.cooked:
Hello Chief Delphi Community, My team is currently working with PathPlanner for our autonomous this year. We are running into a problem where the robot overshoots its destination (Video is below, the robot is supposed to stop at the end of the green tape = 1 meter) We adjusted the PID thinking that would be the solution but it ended up getting better in terms of not overshooting as much but added a new jittering problem. The current values of the PID are kP = 0, kI = 0, kD = 0. These values are present in the video. We are not certain that this is a PID problem. We are open to any possible solutions.

Thanks for any help!

IMG_5933.zip (27.5 MB)

Wespiseb:

The current values of the PID are kP = 0, kI = 0, kD = 0.

If you don’t run any sort of feedback control at all, you are going to have issues following paths as any disturbances or errors in modeling will cause the path to drift without any form of correction.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
The important question is whether the robot knows that it’s overshooting, or thinks that it’s going to the right place. There are a number of ways to check this, including the Field2d widget on your dashboard and Pathplanner telemetry .

It would probably also help if you could share your code.

link_counts.title: The Field2d Widget — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Ben W.
posts.cooked: So the robot does know it is overshooting according to our odometry.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: It’s probably the PID issue that @Alex_Y pointed out, but you should also check that your Pigeon gyro is well-secured. From the video, it looks like it might be just resting on top of the roboRIO. (Also cover your roboRIO ports and insulate your main power.)

posts.name: Ben W.
posts.cooked: Also here is the link to the project. Note: change the branch to Ben-PathPlanner FIRST Team 2472 - 2025 Reefscape bot

posts.name: Ben W.
posts.cooked: Does anyone have a good PID Tuning Strategy?

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: Maybe pathplanner settings are not true but i think that this issue comes from the pid.

posts.name: pinkguava06
posts.cooked: I agree with this. Also make sure your weight settings on Pathplanner are accurate for your robot. It could be trying to compensate for weight that isn’t there.
